titlestmt.titleproper: Rockefeller (Nelson A.) Vice Presidential records, New York Office, Series 10
A Guide to the Nelson A. Rockefeller, Vice Presidential records, New York Office, Series 10 FA380

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-04-06 01:17:45 -0400.

revisiondesc.item: Migrated from Re:discovery to the Archivists' Toolkit by Becky Robbins.

did.unittitle: Nelson A. Rockefeller vice presidential records, New York Office, Series 10

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: United States. Office of the Vice President

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of U.S. copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provide in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection or tems within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: President Gerald R. Ford nominated Nelson A. Rockefeller to fill the vacant vice presidency following the resignation of President Richard M. Nixon in August 1974. Rockefeller served as Vice President from December 19, 1974, to January 20, 1977.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is divided into 3 subseries:
Subseries 1: Vice Presidential Confirmation Hearings, 1974 Subseries 2: Office of the Vice President, 1975-1977 Subseries 3: Sound Recordings, 1974-1977

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: When President Gerald R. Ford selected Nelson A. Rockefeller to fill the vacant vice presidency on August 20, 1974, Rockefeller's staff began preparing material for the confirmation hearings. Much of the material in this series was gathered from the Rockefeller family archives, which was located in Rockefeller Center.

Rockefeller's staff spent most of late August and early September preparing background data, developing drafts of testimony, and fulfilling requests for information from Congressional committee members. The files that begin this series are the products of those efforts.

Once he was confirmed and sworn in as Vice President, Rockefeller and his staff began to accumulate files anew. A new set of subject files was created, as well as files concerned with the daily activities of the Vice President. These files were periodically shipped to the family archives in New York for storage.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids note
otherfindaid.p: Detailed finding aids for each series of this collection are available:

Nelson A. Rockefeller Vice Presidential Records, Working Papers of the Vice President (FA384)
Nelson A. Rockefeller Vice Presidential Records, Foreign Affairs and National Security (FA385)

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Subseries 1 is arranged alphabetically by topic or person.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These files were gathered from the Rockefeller family archives in New York to help prepare testimony and position papers on various issues for the hearings. At the end of each day of testimony, the archive staff gathered information that had been requested that day by the committees and sent it to Washington.

odd.p: Information collected to respond to possible issues that would be raised during the hearings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes a legal brief on the legality of NAR loans to staff and employees; other loan information; list of articles, books, and other publications concerning NAR; NAR medical information supplied by Dr. Kenneth Riland; Proceedings of "Venture Capital and Management" seminar at Boston College; analysis of Library of Congress report on the record of NAR.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Information, documents, and clippings "telecopied" from the Rockefeller family offices in New York to NAR's staff in Washington for use in the hearings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These files were created in Washington and eventually shipped to the family archives in New York. Many of the files contain explanatory memoranda to Dr. Joseph Ernst, the family archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and memoranda concerning the transfer of NAR's gubernatorial files from Albany to the Coach Barn in Pocantico Hills.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Article concerning the artwork in the Vice President's Residence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Transcript of a press conference by NAR in August 1975 in which he is questioned about the Attica prison riot of September 1971.

did.unittitle: Daily Correspondence Traffic Analysis, July 1975 - February 1976

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Exchange of cordial letters between NAR and Mrs. Daringer, one of his schoolteachers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed collection of NAR speeches on issues confronting Americans in 1976.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Background file on the authors of the book, "I Never Wanted to Be Vice President of Anything."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Memo on Job-Scholarships proposal; memo re: Vice Presidential nomination from George L. Hinman in 1976; draft of an acceptance speech for President Ford; NAR notes with names of possible Vice Presidential successors; agenda for meetings with the President on July 22, 1976, including information on minority representation at Republican National Convention; status report on Job Scholarship & School Work proposals; STATUS, a monthly chartbook of Social and Economic Trends; report on New York City (7/21); memo re: black delegates from Dick Allison.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copies of transcripts of briefings in which NAR was mentioned or asked about.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Subseries 3 is grouped by format; first, audio cassettes and then reel-to-reel tapes. Each format is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The third subseries is a collection of reel-to-reel audiotapes and audiocassettes. There are two distinct sets of audiocassettes. The first set consists of recordings of the proceedings of the confirmation hearings; the others are cassette recordings of remarks and speeches made by the Vice President. The reel-to-reel audiotapes are recordings of remarks by the Vice President and other dignitaries.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Original tapes are restricted from scholarly research.

RAC is unable to provide access to obsolete media and original digital media. In addition separated media may not yet have undergone stabilization procedures. When feasible, a digital surrogate may be created via special order. All applicable charges will apply. See RAC Head of Archival Services or RAC Head of Digital Programs for details.
